justification: Table 1 lists Operation Span (Turner & Engle, 1989) as one of the “Commonly Used Working Memory Capacity Tasks,” showing it is employed to index working-memory capacity.
Reading Span (Daneman & Carpenter, 1980) appears in Table 1 under the heading of working-memory measures, indicating it serves to measure working-memory capacity.
Symmetry Span (Unsworth et al., 2009) is included in Table 1 among tasks classified as Complex Span and explicitly noted as a working-memory-capacity measure.
Rotation Span (Kane et al., 2004) is listed in Table 1 under Complex Span tasks used to assess working-memory capacity.
Counting Span (Case et al., 1982) is identified in Table 1 as a Complex Span procedure that ‘is appropriate for young children,’ showing its role as a working-memory measure.
Running Span (Pollack et al., 1959) is tabulated as an Updating-type working-memory task, linking it to the measurement of working-memory capacity.

The N-back (Kirchner, 1958) appears in Table 1 under Updating tasks and is discussed as ‘used widely in neuroscience research,’ though ‘challenged as a measure of WMC,’ confirming it is treated as a working-memory measure.

Mental Counters (Larson & Saccuzzo, 1989) is listed in Table 1 in the Updating category, with notes that its performance is ‘jointly attributable to WMC,’ identifying it as a working-memory assessment.
Backwards Span (Wechsler, 1939) appears in Table 1 under ‘Transposed Serial Recall’ and the notes state it is ‘included … to assess WMC,’ tying it to working-memory capacity.
Letter-Number Sequencing is discussed in Table 1 as ‘Included in the WAIS-IV to assess WMC,’ directly marking it as a working-memory measure.
Table 1 lists Non-Selective Visual Arrays (Luck & Vogel, 1997) with performance ‘transformed into a capacity (k) score,’ designating it as a visual working-memory capacity measure.

The text states, ‘The first, the antisaccade task, … requires the respondent to look away from a flashing distractor… a quintessential example of a situation in which the control of attention is required,’ presenting it as a measure of attention control.

The article explains that ‘individual differences in selective visual arrays are primarily attentional in nature,’ and that the task’s filtering demand ‘produces large individual differences attributable to selective attention,’ identifying it as an attention-control measure.

In the discussion of measurement challenges, the Color Stroop is described as a paradigm where the respondent must ‘resist the automaticity of reading a color word,’ tying its interference score to attention control/inhibition.
The arrow Flanker task (Eriksen & Eriksen, 1974) is grouped with Stroop as a classic ‘conflict or interference task’ used to assess inhibitory aspects of attention control.

When describing improved attention batteries, the authors note that ‘the accuracy analog of the psychomotor vigilance task was just behind [antisaccade and visual arrays]’ among the strongest attention-control measures, indicating it operationalizes attention control.
